metadata.title: Neural Network Interpretability — A review | by Antoine Hue | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: In this post we will go through a comparison of the interpretability of Dense and Convolutional layers of a deep neural network (DNN), still focusing on the image classification task, using the MNIST or CIFAR-10 datasets as examples. But first let's explain briefly what interpretability is and why it is needed.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Explainable Machine Learning for Scientific Insights and Discoveries, R. Roscher, B. Bohn, M-F. Duarte, and J. Garcke
Visualizing Higher-Layer Features of a Deep Network, Erhan et al., 2009
Visualizing and Understanding Convolutional Networks, Zeiler et al., 2013
Deep Inside Convolutional Networks: Visualising Image Classification Models and Saliency Maps, Simonyan et al., 2014
DeepLift: Learning important features through propagating activation differences, Shrikumar et al., 2017
Understanding Neural Networks via Feature Visualization: A survey, Nguyen et al, 2019
Visualizing High-Dimensional Data Using t-SNE, van der Maaten and Hinton
UMAP: Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection for Dimension Reduction, McInns 2018

all_paragraphs: In this post we will go through a comparison of the interpretability of Dense and Convolutional layers of a deep neural network (DNN), still focusing on the image classification task, using the MNIST or CIFAR-10 datasets as examples. But first, let’s explain briefly what interpretability is and why it is needed.

In Part-1, we have shown that Convolutional neural networks are better performing and slimmer than their Dense counterpart using the MNIST canonical dataset as an example. What if this is only a matter of “luck”: it works well on this dataset but would not if the dataset was different or if the task at hand (i.e. classifying handwritten digits) is changing (e.g. classifying machine-generated digits). What exactly the network has learned? There is no definitive answer to these questions. However, there is a whole field of active research on this topic under the umbrella of Interpretability and Adversarial examples.

DNN are based on simple mathematical operations, however, the combination of neurons with non-linear activations over several hidden layers is leading to models that cannot be evaluated with a mathematical formula. This property of the DNN is called a lack of transparency by Roscher. Working around this issue is through interpretability which is defined in the same article as:

“The aim of interpretability is to present some of the properties of an ML model in understandable terms to a human. […] Interpretations can be obtained by way of understandable proxy models, which approximate the predictions of a more complex approach.”
Explainable Machine Learning for Scientific Insights and Discoveries, R. Roscher, B. Bohn, M-F. Duarte, and J. Garcke

Decision trees are quite interpretable as it is possible to look at the importance of each decision variable-threshold. In deep neural networks, there are no such decision artifacts, and other tools are required to inspect the network internals.
Given a neural network, we might be tempted to inspect the weights of each layer. There are two obstacles to this method.

First, the number of weights is quickly in the thousands and is reaching hundreds of millions on the largest networks. Weight aggregation is required, the natural and imperfect statistical tool is the histogram. It remains to find out how aggregation is performed: per neuron unit or per layer?

Given their parameter sharing property, convolutional neural networks (CNN) have an edge: convolutional layer number of weights is much lower than the dense equivalent (see Part-1). Moreover, given the image/signal processing background of the convolution filter, representing their weights is more meaningful than a raw list of weights of a dense layer. Still, this only applies to small networks and first layers.

Second, looking at a single layer’s weight is masking all interactions between layers. We are back at the transparency issue raised here above. The Tensorflow Playground has a representation of this interaction drawing vortices between the layer with a width proportional to the interaction between consecutive neurons. However, this method is difficult to scale.
Another way to look at a network is based on stimuli: the input image(s) in case of an image classification network.

Activation maps are the first interpretation methods based on stimuli: given an image or a small set of images, show the output of each neuron when this image is processed. This mainly applies to CNN as they preserve the 2D structure of the image and is only interpretable in term of geometry artifacts (edges, corners) in the first couple of layers.
More powerful methods have been developed since 2007, all based on the gradient and variations of the same idea: from a given neuron unit or layer, what is the best input to activate it?
Among these methods we may cite:
- Visualizing Higher-Layer Features of a Deep Network, Erhan et al., 2009
- Visualizing and Understanding Convolutional Networks, Zeiler et al., 2013
- Deep Inside Convolutional Networks: Visualising Image Classification Models and Saliency Maps, Simonyan et al., 2014
- DeepLift: Learning important features through propagating activation differences, Shrikumar et al., 2017
- Understanding Neural Networks via Feature Visualization: A survey, Nguyen et al, 2019

The Saliency maps by Erhan and Simonyan are based on the gradient ascent back-propagated up to the network image input (orange path in the figure below). The training process is reversed. During training, the image is part of the ground truth and the network weights are optimized. If the neuron to inspect is the output of the network, we are back to a regular deep neural network optimization but with frozen layer weights (blue path in the figure below).

Saliency maps are close to the adversarial examples as it is possible to create images that have meaning to the network (i.e. predict a given class) but no meaning to our eyes. Here is an example in which a saliency is computed for each of the 10 classes of the CIFAR-10 and then added to an image of the Concord plane. For most classes, the CNN is predicting the class of the saliency with a large margin (probability above 70%):

The initial input image (often called baseline or prior) can be a neutral grey, random noise, or an image of the class we want to inspect. In the last case, the image is modified as if going through caricature. More recent publications as listed by Nguyen have been looking at improving the quality of the saliency maps. The main innovations are on the optimization of the baseline through sampling and aggregation of the classes, and the regularization, penalties increasing the focus of the gradient ascent on the image center, and the smoothness.
Still, this is a very detailed view of the neural network, we are lacking an overview on the classes and on the layers.

Classification neural networks are outputting a very refined and reduced measure: the probability of each class, which is even more summarized to the index of the class with the largest probability. Based on these, the usual metrics is the accuracy which is only counting the number of matching predicted classes versus actual classes. As one of my teachers at Telecom Paris stated:

“Classification neural network last layer is a very simple detector, the one of the logistic or multi-class regression (softmax). The power of the network is the highly non-linear and complex function required to shape the input of this detector.”

A lot of information is present at the input of the last layer. It is providing insights into the network behavior. However, the issue is the same as for previous technics: dimension is very high and cannot be represented easily.
A set of general-purpose dimension reduction technics have been used to display these high dimension spaces as a manifold in the 2D (or 3D) space:

“t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) is a (prize-winning) technique for dimensionality reduction that is particularly well suited for the visualization of high-dimensional datasets. The technique can be implemented via Barnes-Hut approximations, allowing it to be applied on large real-world datasets. We applied it on data sets with up to 30 million examples.”
In Visualizing High-Dimensional Data Using t-SNE, van der Maaten and Hinton, JMLR 2008

“UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a novel manifold learning technique for dimension reduction. UMAP is constructed from a theoretical framework based in Riemannian geometry and algebraic topology. The result is a practical scalable algorithm that applies to real world data. The UMAP algorithm is competitive with t-SNE for visualization quality, and arguably preserves more of the global structure with superior run time performance. Furthermore, UMAP has no computational restrictions on embedding dimension, making it viable as a general purpose dimension reduction technique for machine learning.“
In UMAP: Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection for Dimension Reduction, McInns 2018
If we look at the simple MNIST digit dataset, we may process it directly with UMAP:
The colors correspond to the true digit class. We already see a quite good separation of the class clusters but there are overlapping sections.
If we reuse the Dense network of part 1 and process the softmax layer input, we see that class clusters are better separated and more compact:
And using this nice display made with Bokeh we can inspect the samples that are borderline and maybe misclassified
Same UMAP projection is performed with the LeNet5 CNN architecture :
The clusters are better separated by the CNN, giving an edge to the CNN over the Dense network.
Detail on a set of borderline samples with the CNN:
Most of these technics apply to the neuron unit level and apply to one or a few images. We are clearly missing an overall network view and a domain (dataset) view.
Activation Atlases as proposed by Carter et al. are tackling the dataset overview challenge. Saliency maps are computed over a large sample of the dataset and clustered using t-SNE or UMAP.

We have created a Github project, Deep Neural Network Viewer, to address the network view on toy networks. The project is young and incomplete but already provides some nice view and inspection of CNN and DNN. It will be presented in more detail in a coming post.
The approach is different from the one of Tensorboard Graphs or Netron, they are showing the network topology, but are not linking it to actual performance and parameters (weights, gradients).

We have reviewed a few actual technics to inspect the content of a deep neural network and give interpretation to its results (classification). We have shown that convolutional networks (CNN) are easier to inspect as they preserve the 2D structure of images in the convolutional layers. In our example, we have observed that the performance gain of the CNN over the Dense DNN is visible when representing the input of the last layer with a UMAP projection.

In this post, we have focused on a single task, image classification, which is one among many tasks handled by deep neural networks. Already many different tools and aspects have been listed and their limits are shown. Interpretability of deep neural networks is a very vast field of active research, the demand for more justification of how these systems behavior and robustness is still trending. We will probably deal with it further in future posts.
Here are the notebooks used in this post from the Datascience Step by Step repository:
Data and Computer Scientist, I want AI to be actionable and accessible to everybody
